page.title: 08Chatsworth Gardens
page.content: Your tour of the gardens begins just above the House, where outside the Orangery are the herbaceous borders ablaze with brilliant colours. Beyond the South Front of the House is a lime hedge planted in 1952. Next is the Canal, a long artificial lake with the famous Emperor Fountain, the highest gravity-fed fountain in Europe. At the end of the Canal is the Azalea Dell and then the Pinetum occupying seven acres. The Yew Maze occupies the site of the old Paxton Conservatory. At one end is a bed of 2000 lupins. Below this is the double srepentine beech hedge. Ahead on your right is the Cascade, where water flows down a series of stone steps. There are several greenhouses growing many exotic plants and Paxton's Glass Wall housing mainly Camelias and Peaches.
